visit.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to go and spend time in a place or with someone, especially for pleasure or interest
visit.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Eric went to Seattle to visit his cousins.
I was really pleased that they came to visit me.
Which cities did you visit in Spain?
A recent trip to London gave me the opportunity to visit the Science Museum.
visit.translation[0].definitions[0].note: In everyday English, people often say that they come/go to see someone, rather than visit them:
He’s gone to Scotland to see his family.
visit.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to go to a place as part of your official job, especially to examine it
visit.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The building inspector is visiting the new housing project.
The president’s first trip abroad will be to visit with troops in Bosnia.
visit.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to go to see a doctor, lawyer etc in order to get treatment or advice
visit.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to look at a website on the Internet
visit.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Over 1,000 people visit our site every week.
visit.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Why don’t you kids play outside while we visit with each other?
visit.translation[0].note_box[0].section: a place
visit
to go and spend time in a place, for interest or pleasure
You must visit Kyoto.
They visited all the usual places.
go to
to visit a place. Go to  is very commonly used in everyday English instead of visit
Have you ever been to England?
They went to the Eiffel Tower and the Flea Market.
go sightseeing
to visit places of interest in a country
We went sightseeing in the old part of the city.
a person
visit
to go and spend time with someone
How often do you visit your grandparents?
come around/by/over
to visit someone informally in their home, especially when you live near them
A few friends came round last night.
drop in/by
to visit someone in their home, especially on your way to another place
Kate said she’d drop by later to give you the forms.
look somebody up
to visit someone who you do not see very often, when you are spending time in the area where they live
Look me up if you’re ever in Newark.
visit.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: an occasion when someone goes to spend time in a place or goes to see a person
visit.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: We’re just here on a short visit.
Why don’t you come for a visit this summer?
I decided to pay him a visit at his office.
I’ve just had a visit from the police.
I’m only here for the weekend – just a flying visit this time.
his first official visit to Britain as Russian president
The town is well worth a visit.
visit.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: an occasion when you see a doctor, lawyer etc for treatment or advice
visit.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: an occasion when you talk socially with someone
visit.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: Barbara and I had a nice long visit.
visit.translation[1].note_box[0].section: pay somebody a visit
Perhaps she'll come up to town then and pay me a visit.
make/pay a visit
The king made an official visit to Poland last year.
have/receive a visit from somebody
I've just had a visit from Lou Stacey.
a brief/short visit
Miss Russell was only able to pay a brief visit.
a flying visit
Timpson was due to pay a flying visit to London.
a surprise visit
Naomi paid a surprise visit to an old school friend.
an unannounced visit
The social worker made an unannounced visit.
an official/state visit
The president made an official visit to France this week.
a return visit
George was already planning a return visit.
be worth a visit
Las Palmas, the lively capital, is well worth a visit.
